channel.title: America's Children and the Environment (ACE)
channel.description: Updated America's Children and the Environment (ACE) content from the US Environmental Protection Agency

item.title: ACE Update History
item.description:
October 2015

EPA's website for America's Children and the Environment is now updated with new data for several children's environmental health indicators. The most recent data available are now included in the indicators for the following topics:

  • Criteria Air Pollutants
  • Drinking Water Contaminants
  • Lead
  • Mercury
  • Respiratory Diseases
  • Neurodevelopmental Disorders
item.dc:creator: patrick_tisdel

item.title: Detailed Background on ACE3 for Reviewers, March 2011
item.description:
EPA is preparing a new edition of America’s Children and the Environment (ACE), following the previous editions published in December 2000 and February 2003. ACE is EPA’s compilation of children’s environmental health indicators and related information, drawing on the best national data sources available for characterizing important aspects of the relationship between environmental conditions and children’s health.

  • Introduction to ACE3 (PDF)(8 pp, 132 K)
item.dc:creator: christopher_deloose

item.title: America's Children and the Environment: Second Edition
item.description:
America’s Children and the Environment: Measures of Contaminants, Body Burdens, and Illnesses is the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency’s second report on trends in environmental factors related to the health and well-being of children in the United States.

  • America's Children and the Environment: Second Edition (PDF)(181 pp, 1 MB, February 2003, 240-R-03-001)
item.dc:creator: christopher_deloose

item.title: America's Children and the Environment, Third Edition
item.description:
America’s Children and the Environment (ACE) is EPA’s report presenting data on children’s environmental health. ACE brings together information from a variety of sources to provide national indicators in the following areas: Environments and Contaminants, Biomonitoring, and Health. Environments and Contaminants indicators describe conditions in the environment, such as levels of air pollution. Biomonitoring indicators include contaminants measured in the bodies of children and women of child-bearing age, such as children’s blood lead levels. Health indicators report the rates at which selected health outcomes occur among U.S. children, such as the annual percentage of children who currently have asthma. Accompanying each indicator is text discussing the relevance of the issue to children’s environmental health and describing the data used in preparing the indicator. Wherever possible, the indicators are based on data sources that are updated in a consistent manner, so that indicator values may be compared over time.

  • America's Children and the Environment, Third Edition (PDF)(504 pp, 13 MB, January 2013, 240-R-13-001)
item.dc:creator: christopher_deloose

item.title: America’s Children and the Environment: A First View of Available Measures
item.description:
The report’s principal authors and project managers were Tracey J. Woodruff and Daniel A. Axelrad, of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency’s (EPA) National Center for Environmental Economics, and Amy D. Kyle, of the University of California at Berkeley, School of Public Health. This report was edited by Brad Hurley of ICF Consulting. This report would not be possible with out the support and leadership of Ramona Trovato, Director of the Office of Children’s Health Protection and Al McGartland, Director of the National Center for Environmental Economics.

  • ACE Report (PDF)(91 pp, 1 MB, December 2000, 240-R-00-006)
item.dc:creator: christopher_deloose

item.title: ACE Related Topics and Links
item.description:
• America's Children: Key National Indicators of Well-Being Exit: This report provides data on important aspects of U.S. children’s lives in the areas of family and social environment, economic circumstances, health care, physical environment and safety, behavior, education, and health.
  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC): Children’s Environmental Health Tracking Exit: This site provides data for the incidence of several childhood diseases (e.g., asthma, cancer, lead poisoning, developmental disabilities) and socioeconomic conditions.
  • U.S. EPA: Child-specific Exposure Factors Handbook: This handbook provides information on physiological and behavioral factors that are used to assess children’s exposure to environmental chemicals.
  • U.S. EPA: Children's Environmental Health Facts: This page provides facts about asthma, lead exposure, childhood cancer, and developmental disabilities.
  • U.S. EPA: What You Can Do to Protect Children from Environmental Risks: This page offers tips on how to protect children from a variety of environmental risks.
  • U.S. EPA: Office of Children's Health Protection - Publications: Links to a wide variety of publications related to children’s health and the environment.
  • National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (NIEHS): Children's Health Exit: This page describes what NIEHS is doing in the area of children’s health, and provides links to information relevant to the topic.
  • World Health Organization (WHO): Global Plan of Action for Children's Health and the Environment Exit: This site provides details on WHO’s initiatives related to children’s health, along with information on children’s health in general.
item.dc:creator: patrick_tisdel
